Petit Institute for Bioengineering and Bioscience (IBB)</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/27185" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>The heart of Georgia Tech's thriving life sciences community</subtitle> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/27185</id> <updated>2015-03-06T08:37:10Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-06T08:37:10Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Mechanoreception of Adhesion and Signaling Molecules on the Cell Surface</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52845" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Zhu, Cheng</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52845</id> <updated>2014-11-28T08:31:23Z</updated> <published>2014-11-11T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Mechanoreception of Adhesion and Signaling Molecules on the Cell Surface Zhu, Cheng Presented on November 11, 2014 from 8:30-9:30 am in IBB Building room 1128.; Cheng Zhu is the Executive Director for International Programs, J. Erskine Love Endowed Chair in Engineering, and Regents' Professor of the Wallace H. Coulter Deptartment of Biomedical Engineering at Georgia Tech.; Runtime:  53:20 minutes </summary> <dc:date>2014-11-11T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Zhu, Cheng</dc:creator> </entry> <entry> <title>The Spinal Cord: Parallel/Distributed Processor Regulating Limb Mechanics</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52663" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Nichols, T. Richard</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52663</id> <updated>2014-10-28T07:31:29Z</updated> <published>2014-10-14T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">The Spinal Cord: Parallel/Distributed Processor Regulating Limb Mechanics Nichols, T. Richard The work in the Neurophysiology Laboratory is focused on mechanisms underlying motor coordination in mammalian systems. These mechanisms are to be found in the structure and dynamic properties of the musculoskeletal system as well as in the organization of neuronal circuits in the central nervous system. Our work concerns the interactions between the musculoskeletal system and spinal cord that give rise to normal and abnormal movement and posture, and in the manner in which central pattern-generating networks are modified for specific motor tasks. Their studies have applications in several movement disorders, including spinal cord injury. The experimental approaches span a number of levels, from mechanical studies of isolated muscle cells to kinematic measurements of natural behavior in quadrupeds. T. Richard Nichols is a Professor and Chair of the School of Applied Physiology at Georgia Tech.  His research interests are focused on mechanisms underlying motor coordination in mammalian systems.; Presented on October 14 from 8:30-9:30 am in IBB Building room 1128.; Runtime:  55:53 minutes </summary> <dc:date>2014-10-14T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Nichols, T. Richard</dc:creator> <dc:description>The work in the Neurophysiology Laboratory is focused on mechanisms underlying motor coordination in mammalian systems. These mechanisms are to be found in the structure and dynamic properties of the musculoskeletal system as well as in the organization of neuronal circuits in the central nervous system. Our work concerns the interactions between the musculoskeletal system and spinal cord that give rise to normal and abnormal movement and posture, and in the manner in which central pattern-generating networks are modified for specific motor tasks. Their studies have applications in several movement disorders, including spinal cord injury. The experimental approaches span a number of levels, from mechanical studies of isolated muscle cells to kinematic measurements of natural behavior in quadrupeds.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>RNA and Protein: A Match Made in the Hadean</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52371" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Williams, Loren</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52371</id> <updated>2014-09-28T07:31:26Z</updated> <published>2014-09-09T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">RNA and Protein: A Match Made in the Hadean Williams, Loren Biological systems record historical information, as seen in the growth rings of trees. On a molecular level, records are detailed and extensive, connecting us to the pre-history of biology (the origin of life). The most ancient macromolecules in biology are found in the ribosome, which is the RNA-protein complex responsible for the synthesis of all coded protein in living organisms. The catalytic core of the ribosome a deeply-frozen molecular fossil that is older than modern biology. The origins and early development of the ribosome, billions of years ago, remain firmly imprinted in the biochemistry of extant life. The ribosome tells us part of the story of the origin of life. The information contained within the ribosome guides our laboratory in experimentally recapitulating critical chemical and biochemical steps in the origin and early evolution of life. Loren Williams is the Director, NASA-NAI RiboEvo Center and a Professor in the School of Chemistry and Biochemistry.  In 1981 he received his B.Sc. in Chemistry from the University of Washington where he worked in the laboratory of Martin Gouterman. In 1985 he received his Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from Duke University, where he worked the laboratory of Barbara Shaw. He was an American Cancer Society Postdoctoral Fellow first at Duke then at Harvard. From 1988 to 1992 he was an NIH Postdoctoral Fellow with Alex Rich in the Department of Biology at MIT. He joined the School of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Georgia Tech in 1992 where is he currently a professor. Loren received an NSF CAREER Award in 1995, and a Sigma Xi Award for best paper from Georgia Tech in 1996.; Presented on September 9, 2013 from 8:30-9:30 am in IBB Building room 1128.; Runtime:  59:13 minutes </summary> <dc:date>2014-09-09T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Williams, Loren</dc:creator> <dc:description>Biological systems record historical information, as seen in the growth rings of trees. On a molecular level, records are detailed and extensive, connecting us to the pre-history of biology (the origin of life). The most ancient macromolecules in biology are found in the ribosome, which is the RNA-protein complex responsible for the synthesis of all coded protein in living organisms. The catalytic core of the ribosome a deeply-frozen molecular fossil that is older than modern biology. The origins and early development of the ribosome, billions of years ago, remain firmly imprinted in the biochemistry of extant life. The ribosome tells us part of the story of the origin of life. The information contained within the ribosome guides our laboratory in experimentally recapitulating critical chemical and biochemical steps in the origin and early evolution of life.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Autonomous Mobile Robots for Personalized Caregiving</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52136" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Kemp, Charles C.</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/52136</id> <updated>2014-09-05T07:32:21Z</updated> <published>2014-08-12T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Autonomous Mobile Robots for Personalized Caregiving Kemp, Charles C. Mobile robots with autonomous capabilities have the potential to provide 24/7 personalized care, dramatically improving the quality of life of people with motor impairments. I will first provide an overview of opportunities for robots to provide beneficial physical assistance in the context of healthcare. I will then focus on my lab\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research to enable people with severe motor impairments to perform everyday tasks for themselves using mobile robots. In particular, I will focus on our work with Henry Evans, who has severe impairments due to a brain stem stroke. Through our research, Henry has been able to perform a number of tasks for himself for the first time in 10 years, such as pulling a blanket over himself, shaving himself, and operating mechanisms in his home. A key aspect of our work has been giving robots the ability to intelligently regulate the forces they apply while providing assistance. Presented on August 12, 2014 from 8:30-9:30 am in IBB Building room 1128 on the Georgia Tech campus.; Charles C. Kemp (Charlie) is an Associate Professor at the Georgia Institute of Technology in the Department of Biomedical Engineering at Georgia Tech and Emory and is an adjunct faculty member of the School of Interactive Computing and the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering. He earned a doctorate in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (2005), an MEng, and BS from MIT. In 2007, he founded the Healthcare Robotics Lab at Georgia Tech (http://healthcare-robotics.com), which focuses on mobile manipulation and human-robot interaction.; Runtime:  63:35 minutes </summary> <dc:date>2014-08-12T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Kemp, Charles C.</dc:creator> <dc:description>Mobile robots with autonomous capabilities have the potential to provide 24/7 personalized care, dramatically improving the quality of life of people with motor impairments. I will first provide an overview of opportunities for robots to provide beneficial physical assistance in the context of healthcare. I will then focus on my lab\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research to enable people with severe motor impairments to perform everyday tasks for themselves using mobile robots. In particular, I will focus on our work with Henry Evans, who has severe impairments due to a brain stem stroke. Through our research, Henry has been able to perform a number of tasks for himself for the first time in 10 years, such as pulling a blanket over himself, shaving himself, and operating mechanisms in his home. A key aspect of our work has been giving robots the ability to intelligently regulate the forces they apply while providing assistance.</dc:description> </entry> </feed>
